awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative Research: A Blueprint for Photocatalytic Water Splitting: Mapping Multidimensional Compositional Space to Simultaneously Optimize Thermodynamics and Kinetics
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Sunlight is a vast source of renewable energy but its intermittent nature means that its utilization requires a means of storing this energy. One attractive approach for solar energy storage is to harness the energy of sunlight to split water into hydrogen and oxygen i.e. solar generated fuels. The solar generated fuels can be combusted to release energy efficiently with water as the only by-product. As a result, this approach avoids the deleterious consequences of greenhouse emissions that accompany the combustion of conventional fossil fuels. The complex cascade of reactions required to harvest sunlight and split water into hydrogen and oxygen present a formidable scientific challenge. The project seeks to develop hybrid materials as the catalyst for water splitting, such that individual components are assembled and function synergistically. The project further works towards employing components that are highly tunable in terms of their energy levels, thereby providing a versatile platform that can be optimized for converting sunlight and water into fuel.  Employing a judicious mix of calculations from supercomputers and selective experiments accelerates the rationally design of materials for efficient solar energy storage within chemical bonds. The project team mentors young scientists from underrepresented groups and engages K-12 students and teachers in activities that emphasize the opportunities made available by big data and solar energy.

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The project explores the design of programmable heterostructured platforms for photocatalytic water splitting based on interfacing ternary vanadium oxide bronzes with semiconductor quantum dots. In the former compounds, metal cations are intercalated within a variety of open vanadium oxide frameworks, enabling a multitude of compositional possibilities and considerable energy level tuning. Moreover, the energy levels of quantum dots can also be tuned as a function of composition as well as size and the presence of cores. Photocatalytic water splitting requires not just the appropriate alignment of energy levels but also precise control of charge transfer dynamics. Interfacing two versatile and tunable components yields a rich multidimensional space for identification of effective photocatalytic architectures for water oxidation that yield holes at potentials only minimally positive to the water oxidation potential, thereby allowing for efficient conversion of sunlight to solar fuels. The multidimensional parameter space is mapped through a closely integrated and iterative combination of first-principles structure prediction, electronic structure calculations, diversified materials synthesis, detailed spectroscopy, high-throughput screening, and big data analytics. The activity involves development of an open-source platform for statistical analysis and mining of spectroscopic data. A summer research activity engages undergraduates from diverse backgrounds.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Our collaborative DMREF project involves theory-guided design, synthesis, and characterization of quantum dot (QD)/MxV2O5 heterostructures with programmable properties for photocatalytic water splitting. Photocatalysis involves transfer of excited-state holes from QDs into mid-gap states of MxV2O5 nanowires (NWs), reduction of protons at the QD, and oxidation of water. The heterostructures are intended to serve as the light-harvesting and charge-separating components of photocathodes of water-splitting photoelectrochemical cells (PECs) with a view towards building an artificial leaf that generates solar fuels using just water and sunlight as feedstock. The design space of the heterostructures is vast, encompassing (1) V—O connectivity of many V2O5 polymorphs; (2) the cation M that governs the energy of mid-gap states; (3) the identity of a co-intercalating cation Mʹ in MyʹMxV2O5;  (4) the composition of QDs; and (5) structure of the MxV2O5/QD interface. Given the vast compositional and structural matrix, we have undertaken an iterative approach involving first-principles theory; materials synthesis aided by sequential learning, high-throughput characterization, and artificial-intelligence-driven data analytics; spectroscopic studies of electronic structure and charge-transfer dynamics; and experimental characterization of photocatalysis. Specifically, we have sought to (1) design, synthesize, and characterize heterostructures with tunable energetic offsets and (2) improve systematically their interfacial charge-transfer reactivity and performance as photocatalyst platforms for water-splitting PECs.

 

The culmination of five iterative cycles has enabled us to converge on fourth-generation photocatalytic architectures exhibiting efficacious photocatalytic hydrogen evolution and has allowed us to establish a vast foundry of single crystals that have yielded rich design principles. Progress towards fully functional catalysts has been greatly accelerated by the construction of a first-principles framework, which has been rigorously improved by hard X-ray photoemission spectroscopy and resonant inelastic X-ray scattering measurements, mechanistic elucidation of dynamics of charge transfer, a deep-learning-based model and extensive curated database for hyperspectral image analysis, and a machine learning and robotic synthesis platform that has greatly accelerated navigation of the synthetic design space.

Intellectual Merit

Gen. I: Pb0.33V2O5/CdE (E = S, Se). We initially predicted and measured intercalative mid-gap states of β-Pb0.33V2O5, and thus hypothesized that these mid-gap states could accept excited holes from QDs to initiate redox photocatalysis. Next, we synthesized β-Pb0.33V2O5/CdE heterostructures via successive ionic layer adsorption and reaction (SILAR) and linker-assisted assembly (LAA). Hard X-ray emission spectroscopy revealed energetic overlap between the valence band of CdE QDs and mid-gap states of β-Pb0.33V2O5. We discovered that photoexcited QDs indeed transfers holes to β-Pb0.33V2O5 on sub-picosecond time scales, and that β-Pb0.33V2O5/CdE photocathodes reduce H+ to H2 with Faradaic efficiencies >90%.

Gen. II/III: β-Sn0.23V2O5/QD. In a signature accomplishment, we designed 2nd-gen. heterostructures with rationally-improved electronic structure. We modeled β-MxV2O5 compounds and predicted that Sn2+ would yield mid-gap states at ideal energies to extract holes from excited QDs. We then designed a topochemical synthesis in which Sn2+ was inserted into metastable ζ-V2O5. We further interfaced β-Sn0.33V2O5 with CdSe QDs. HAXPES revealed improved overlap of mid-gap states with valence states of CdSe. Finally, we measured sub-picosecond hole transfer from CdSe QDs to β-Sn0.33V2O5, preventing photoanodic corrosion of CdSe, and enabling efficient photocatalytic reduction of H+ to H2.

Gen.-IV heterostructures. Applying design principles learned from our single-crystal foundry, we recently designed novel Sb2VO5/CdE heterostructures. Sb2VO5 provides a high density of Sb 5s2-derived states, which facilitate nearly-barrierless hole transfer from CdS. Sb2VO5/CdS heterostructures photocatalyze a range of redox reactions including HER at CdS with concomitant oxidation of H2O at Sb2VO5. We have also recently developed heterostructures in which QDs are interfaced with the reduction co-catalyst MoS2, which undergo ultrafast electron transfer and reduce H+ to H2 with Faradaic efficiency of 99.4%, 40× greater than CdS QDs alone.

Broader Impacts

We have devised deep learning, statistical learning, and data regression workflows to accelerate characterization of our compounds and to more rapidly and effectively learn from spectroscopy data. Specifically, we have devised a systematic workflow for (a) segmentation and particle size analysis trained using synthetic datasets; and (b) high-accuracy composition, phase, and strain mapping across individual particles and ensembles of particles combining singular value decomposition, principal-component analysis, k-means clustering, and linear combination fitting, in conjunction with a curated spectral database. Web-based interactive tools for on-the-fly image analyses have been made available on Github. The publicly available curated databases, complete workflows, and interactive web tools provide an illustration of real-time learnings from characterization data, which can be used to control features such as composition and particle geometry during autonomous synthesis.

We have established deep industrial ties and have begun to directly address materials criticality and supply chain issues through construction of one-of-a-kind geological deposit and co-production database.

We have contributed to a longstanding partnership with UPR-Cayey’s RISE program, and have mentored 10 URM undergraduate summer interns from UPR-Cayey who contributed to the collaborative project.

 


Last Modified: 08/02/2023
Modified by: Sarbajit Banerjee

por.por_txt_cntn:
Our collaborative DMREF project involves theory-guided design, synthesis, and characterization of quantum dot (QD)/MxV2O5 heterostructures with programmable properties for photocatalytic water splitting. Photocatalysis involves transfer of excited-state holes from QDs into mid-gap states of MxV2O5 nanowires (NWs), reduction of protons at the QD, and oxidation of water. Progress towards fully functional catalysts has been greatly accelerated by the construction of a first-principles framework, which has been rigorously improved by hard X-ray photoemission spectroscopy and resonant inelastic X-ray scattering measurements, mechanistic elucidation of dynamics of charge transfer, a deep-learning-based model and extensive curated database for hyperspectral image analysis, and a machine learning and robotic synthesis platform that has greatly accelerated navigation of the synthetic design space.
